citeinfo.origin:
Institute of Cetacean Research, Japan
National Science Museum, Japan
citeinfo.title: Marine Mammals Stranding Database

abstract.p: This database is compiled to cover marine mammals stranding data collected by the Institute of Cetacean Research since 1986. Retrospective efforts are also made and the oldest data dates back to 1901. Biological data include species name, sex, length, weight, situation, lat./long., date, and so on. Species include dolphins, porpoises, sea otters, seals, walruses, and whales stranded in the East China Sea, Sea of Okhotsk, Sea of Japan, Pacific Ocean, and etc.

purpose.p: More than 100 strandings of cetaceans are reported each year. Stranded animals not only convey various data, such as distribution, migration, life history, etc., but provide important specimens for the researches in anatomy, pathology or parasitology, otherwise difficult to collect. They also provide us samples that can be used for detecting contaminants. Helping live strandings will save specific geographical populations, and moreover provide opportunities to study evaluating human impacts on the populations. This database is a part of "Marine Mammal Database" and will support users to identify marine mammal species by digital image transfer, will help locate specimens and so on.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.
